turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And without probable cause, you can make the search in connection to shooting that search was invalid?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You're not resting on the any sort of approach that the state can in Harris, just before this Court.

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Well, Your Honor we are to say that the Harris case of --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) have the right to custody of this car to impound it and -- and whether it was the sheriff or may it be somebody else who want to search this car is to inventory.

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, in the Harris case and also in the Cooper case, I have difficulty in saying where those statutes authorizing these searches merely -- I mean, merely because the statutes provides it, they can be impounded has anything to do with the Fourth Amendment guarantees of the search.

This, to me would seem to be that state's statute in conflict with the federal constitution would prevail but certainly it's not true and I have difficulty seeing how this makes any difference even in the Harris case or the Cooper case.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Mr. Carter, why don't you get a search warrant?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: We are --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is there any explanation at the record that why they didn't?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: No sir.
There is no explanation --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do you have any?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: No sir.
I can't at the time this was done, it was late at night for that matter.

I can well explain why that there is no search warrant gotten because in other cases there shows that the magistrates were closed by so to speak and things like that in this case, there is -- I mean there's nothing --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: How far was the magistrate away in this town?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: He was --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: How large is the town?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: It's very small, 14,000 people.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, he wasn't too far away from --

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: No sir, he wouldn't be too far away of it.
I mean, the record but it's a mile half away.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: And some 12 o'clock at night.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What time of night was it?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: It was midnight or rather around that time.
The shooting occurred approximately 11 o'clock.
They were stopped at approximately 11:30 some miles from the place where the shooting took place and immediately take him to the jail and thereafter the car was immediately searched --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Now, they saw a bullet hole in this -- in the back of this car?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: In the earlier shooting had there been exchange of shots?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Just one shot fired into this?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: No sir.
There had been an exchange.

There was only one shot that hit the automobile as it as leaving there and the Sheriff in Monroe County, the adjoining county where the shooting took place was aware of the shooting episode and he put it out over the radio that shooting episode had taken place.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But not -- where those his words, this shooting episode took place?
It doesn't sound like there are many sheriffs in Tennessee?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Well, I don't know how you would --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Does the record show what he did say, in other words, I'm interested in the bullet hole?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Yes sir.
The record shows by Sheriff Kirkpatrick what was put out of the broadcast -- I mean concerning the shooting episode --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That was a kind of old car.

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: --see that in the record but there was there anything about this shooting episode as you call it would being described as an exchange of shots --

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: There's nothing in there to show --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) along with a simple a stray shot from somebody in an automobile into a house?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: There is nothing in the record to show that Sheriff Powers knew that there had been an exchange of gun fire but to point that question out, if it please the Court, I think that any officer would be correct in assuming that where there was a shooting episode that there was an exchange of gun fire and as --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: First of all, as I understand it, the word episode doesn't appear in the record.

Secondly, it's -- I don't think we can in normal expectation about anything you can have a shot fired from moving automobile into a house or you can have an exchange of gun fire and I wonder if there was anything in this record showing that these people knew that there has been an exchange of gun fire.
In short, I'm wondering if the presence of that bullet hole in the back of the car helps the case for probable cause that's all.

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: I certainly think it does.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well now, why?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: I think the frank that these people when stopped said that it was an old bullet hole which was obviously contrary to the side of it as testified not only by Sheriff Powers but Sheriff Canon to the effect that it was fresh because it had absolutely no rust around it.
I think that this was in conflict with normal senses and so forth to this extent.
All of this evidence in this record stands uncontradicted concerning the fact that as to the opinion that Sheriff Canon had, he said that in his opinion that the shot have been made that very night.
All these stands uncontradicted and I think that the fact the bullet hole was in the rear of the automobile certainly gave rise to this matter of probable cause.
Not only was he stopped for reckless driving but he was stopped because the officer had reason to believe that this serious offense shooting in this home in this adjoining county had been committed.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Had been what?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Committed.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, your problem is that seems to me that Supreme Court of Tennessee based its decision on the proposition that the search was made for evidence of the crime for which these people were arrested that's on page 45 of the joint appendix and that would be the crime of reckless driving.

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Well, Your Honor I think that the opinion further went on to say that under all the fashion and circumstances in the case that it had met the test of whether or not the search was reasonable.
I think the opinion --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Where is that?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: It's --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Because on page 45 the -- I'm looking onto this I am.
The Court says that so long as the State Tennessee there have been reasonable limits.

First, the police may search pursuant to a lawful arrest the person and the property of the person arrested for evidence of the crime for which he is arrested and for weapons which might be utilized for resistance in order to escape.

Now, if that is the -- if that's state correctly states the law applied here and if the correct states the limit of Tennessee law and I just one would have to conclude that the search here has to be justified in terms of the reckless driving arrest.

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Well, further I mean, this went on that the search conducted with then, the reasonable limits and I can't speak for a Court to certain what they say and I can't --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Within those reasonable limits but the Court says that (a) it's got to be reasonable and (b) that it's got to be for evidence of the crime for which he is arrested and for weapons which might be utilized for assistance or escape.

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Your Honor, when they point out this also that immediately after the Sheriff of the adjoining county arrived in which the shooting took place, these men were taken back to Monroe County where the shooting occurred and at that time they were charge for shooting in to this house and certainly --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That is by criminal information or criminal charge?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And that's the one that subsequently been nolle?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Yes sir, that was nolle on prosequi.

Now, in regard to the question of whether or not this case required a jury trial in the contempt proceeding has been argued time and again and certainly one of the points to be raised in this case was whether or not the question on the Sixth Amendment and the Fourteenth Amendment was properly brought to your attention on the Supreme Court of Tennessee.

In the petitioner's brief, they indicate that certainly that this issue is preposterous because throughout the proceedings that they were relying on a jury trial but nowhere in the assignments of error in the Supreme Court of Tennessee was a question of the Sixth Amendment or the Fourteenth Amendment ever raised, the only constitutional amendment, I'll say this, it was in the propositions of law in the brief which they presented they included it in the propositions of law.
But in the brief which followed it was not mentioned.
The only place which it was mentioned are these amendments were mentioned where in the propositions of law.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, the Tennessee Supreme Court passed on it in terms of Article VII.

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Yes sir, that was the -- I mean, this was in the assignment of error which was right, I mean raised by the petitioners.

They said that they were relying on the Seventh Amendment and this was specifically raised in the assignment of error but the Sixth Amendment and the Fourteenth Amendment were not raised in the assignment of error.
The only place was in the proposition of law.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Will you forgive me for reverting to our earlier colloquy?
Were these people -- was driver of this car of a prosecuted for reckless driving?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Not.
I can't answer that.
I don't know whether he was prosecuted for reckless driving or not.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Would you be prosecuted for anything, any crime in this contempt where this episode that we're talking about it?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Well, I'll answer this way, if it please the Court.
He was in -- I mean these three gentlemen were indicted in Monroe County for this crime and they --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Any other copy?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Not where the -- not where the shooting took place?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: No.
Where the shooting took place was where they were indicted.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: And immediately after the indictment was presented and so forth they then paid because and the fine -- I mean, in the charge was reduced and under Tennessee law when you nolle on the payment of the cost you cannot thereafter have another indictment return it against you and over if you did if we double jeopardy.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What was the crime reduced to?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: It wasn't reduced as such which is dismissed on the payment of the cost.
It was dismissed, the indictment was dismissed.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Some kind of a compromise reason.

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Well, I mean there I can't speak for the Attorney General even there because I wouldn't do him nothing that I was at the trial at that time but it was dismissed.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I see your court said that in connection with this arrest that you may issue a search warrant search pursuant to a lawful arrest yet was for reckless driving, was it?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The person and property of the person arrested evidence of the crime for which he arrested and for weapon which might be utilized for resistance or escape --

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- I presume your argument is that the pistol that have been used for resistance of this case, is that right?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: I think that the -- I think that anytime when people have weapon so called in their control I mean that's certainly that they have a right to search for it and ask what the Court held.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Are you arguing that the fact that there have been this previous shooting whether it was made the basis of an arrest or not would have something to do with the reasonable circumstances in connection with the entire case in determining whether or not there was probable cause?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Mr. Carter, --

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: -- at the time the car was searched there was no charge then and against two and reckless driving against third man.

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: That's true.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And the all three were in custody in the jail, is that correct?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, they -- as such substantially that is correct but I might say that they were not in a cell as such, they were sitting on the bench as you walk through the front door of the jail but they were not --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Could they walk out?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: As to the facts as to whether or not they could've walked out, I can only assume that two of them could've walked out.
They weren't being prevented from walking out or anything like that.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, I thought you admitted they were under restraint.

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: I say substantially that they were under restraint to the effect pending further in --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, restraint means restraints.
Do you agree that restraint mean you can't walk off?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, what danger was a loaded weapon in the car if they could get out to the jail?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Well, Your Honor I think that would get back to the questions to whether or not the car be held as evidence in the -- if in fact the car could --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, do you agree that he didn't search the car for their own protection?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Well, I -- the record doesn't say while he searched the car but I would only be (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, is there any claim made that the Sheriff's searching was own protection?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: I don't think so.
No sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: I'm saying this that the car was in a public place and that under this -- under the circumstances any one of these men's confederates are associates could've gone to the car and remove evidence which was contained in the car concerning the shooting which occurred in Monroe County.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes, the policeman was stationed there to watch?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: If a sheriff's deputy or policeman was stationed there to watch the car, could they have done it?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Then it would be -- I mean it would go back as to a question of control if the car was in fact being held as evidence then I think that the officers had the right to search the car if in fact it was still under the control of the defendant McKinney then I think that any of his associates are --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, let's talk on control.
Who had the keys to the car?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: As far as the keys -- I don't know who had the keys to the car.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, you know the defendants didn't have it because they came in the Sheriff's car and somebody else brought their car.

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: That's right.
But I don't know that the defendants didn't have keys at that time after they arrived.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: He was still under restraint.

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Yes sir.
Going further in the -- if I might, the matter goes as to whether or not these defendants were entitled to a jury trial in the state court.

For -- I mean, for the prosecution as such for contempt criminal contempt it's -- has long been the rule in that state and for many, many years is of course well knows was a law down to which you might call the Barnett case that under the criminal law that all courts have the right to -- I mean, punish some merely for violation of the court order or an order of its court.
Now, in the Sheriff case, the federal case why it provided of course that the six months was -- I mean was the ruling was of test.
In the case at bar the maximum penalty under Tennessee law was 10 days in jail and a $50.00 fine.

I mean, throughout the arguments presented by the petitioners they indicate that because what they did in the State of Tennessee was a felony that they were entitled to a jury trial but in effect what they were been tried for was the violation of the court order.

Now, there are some comment concerning the reason for the court order and so forth, I might point out that the injunction order which was handed down, which was issued in the case was an agreed order.

It was agreed on by the attorney's for the petitioners concerning the enjoinment of violence and so forth and this is a common practice in all states I think which have so-called right to work law so where the people who do not choose to strike continue to go to work then they're protected under the law from any harm that might come to them by people who are on the picket lines or elsewhere for that matter.

Now, in this case it -- I mean it goes back to a question as whether or not the Sixth Amendment applies to the states even in the jury trial through the Fourteenth Amendment and certainly it's our position that had this case a reason in the federal court system with the maximum penalty of 10 days in jail as provide by law and a $50.00 fine that in a federal system that this punishment would be -- I might say, this punishment would be proper under the Sheriff's case.

And to say that it would not be proper in the State of Tennessee where there is in some question is to whether or not the Sixth and the Fourteenth Amendment apply to the jury trial question in state court.

It's somewhat difficult for me to comprehend in view of the fact that the Sixth and Fourteenth Amendment to the state court concerning jury questions are -- I mean is -- that is excuse me, questionable.
Now, --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: May I ask you?

Assuming that in one of these cases I don't say there's any such thing possible or likely, assuming in one of the cases that's been argued this week, the Court should reach the conclusion the Fourteenth Amendment made this provision, jury trial provision applicable to the state, what would be your position then?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Well, I would say that under the Sheriff case where the -- it was permitted the six month since it was permitted they tried summarily without a jury.

I would say that that certain apply in this case where the maximum sentence is only 10 days and a $50.00 fine and I think that even if the Court did hold that the Sixth and Fourteenth Amendment were applicable to the states that under Sheriff -- I mean you would have the same result here they were not tried for jury trial.

Now, the cases goes back as concerning whether or not this car can be held as evidence and to whether or not the search under that question was -- I mean, was justified and it's the position of the respondent that under all the facts and circumstances of the case this search was reasonable and that the constitutional rights of the defendants were not or the petitioners were not violated by the search nor were they violated by the fact that they were not presented with the jury trial.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: How relevant do you think this pistol was, what's the point that he declared, I think convicted the man on contempt such what you have it?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It was all put in the contempt proceeding whether they?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: It was not presented to the Court in the contempt case.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, then why is it (Voice Overlap).

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: I'll put it this way, it was not ever seen -- I mean, the weapon was never seen by the chancellor of the -- I mean the bullets were never seen by the chancellor.
He made a comment that -- I mean, to treat as file in withdrawn but I mean in actuality it was never there, he never saw it.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Was it introduced.

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Well, like I say he said that to treat as filed and withdrawn but it was never seen by the chancellor.
In fact, it was still in Monroe County --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: -- the adjoining county.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It was not introduced in evidence, what does it have to do with this case?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Well, Your Honor this is -- we go back to the question of the Chapman case concerning the harmless error as I understand things of this nature that you have to show that --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, infringement Chapman --

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Well, --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- it was trying to find out if it was actually play the part in this case.

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: I can't answer as to the fact that it did without being -- I mean, without speaking for the chancellor.
He made a comment that he had waived the evidence, all the evidence which he had heard in its severe form and that he found that they guilty the unreasonable doubt.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Was there any effort motion to suppress it?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And was that passed on?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Yes sir.
That was passed on.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, why wouldn't that bring it here?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: You mean -- I mean concerning the weapon?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Suppress the weapon as evidence, was there a motion made to suppress it?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: If used as evidence?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And the Court rule on that.

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: Yes sir.
They overrule as such concerning that testimony concerning this, the finding of this gun.
That's right.

They -- I mean the testimony was there that these officers had seen it that the ammunition which they found in the front seat of the automobile was comparative, I mean was the same type of ammunition which was found at the home into whose house the bullet was fired.
In other words, the same projectile and it was a different type projectile.

In other words, it was similar to attorney to a lawful projectile and that the sheriff testified that he had never seen anything like it but the one that was found at the home of where the shooting took place and the ones which were found in the front seat of the car were the same.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But it was there relevant, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: allen_h_carter
turn.label: Mr. Allen H. Carter
turn.text: I think for that question that it was relevant, yes sir.
Thank you very much.
Thank you.
